body.head: The development of the Au Lac State.

p.s: 1. The development in production.
Through making or casting metal working tools and weapons, the Au Lac people step by step learnt the technique to produce similar iron ones.
Besides bronze ploughshares which were widely used, iron hoes and spades began to appear.
Buffaloes and oxen also began to be used as pulling power which helped make hard ploughing faster and easier.
More rice, potatoes, beans, etc.
were produced as a result of which livestock breeding achieved a relevant growth.
The number of livestock such as cattle buffaloes, oxen, pigs, dogs, etc grew very fast in number.
Fruit trees such as banana, orange, lychee, longan, coconut, custard apple, etc.
were grown in home gardens.
Betel and areca were grown by each household.
The new progress in making handicrafts gave rise to the development of pottery production, mining and metallurgy.
Pottery craftsmen produced a large number of jars, pots, bowls, etc., which served as common items for daily life.
Pottery consisted of both fine and rough types.
They were baked at high temperature and became much stronger.
Bricks and tiles were also baked for construction.
The Au Lac were able to cast many bronze utensils and jewels.
Things to be buried with the dead were also cast in bronze.
2. Au Lac's State apparatus and society.
The Au Lac kingdom under An Duong Vuong's reign was divided into bo (regions).
Below each bo were communes (village and hamlet).
An Duong Vuong was the head of the Au Lac kingdom.
The king was also the owner of the entire land and leader of the army with the power to appoint the dignitaries.
Heading a region was a Lac tuong (military chief) and heading each commune was a Bo chinh (village elder).
Although the number of dignitaries accounted for a small section of the population, they were powerful and wealthy.
Members of the commune served as principal workers of the society.
They had to contribute part of their rice yield or products to the king and the aristocrats.
They were compulsorily sent to construction sites to build public works such as dykes, dams or taken for the service in the army.
Serfs totally depended on their lords and could be put on sale or exchange by the latter.
The number of serfs increased in the Au Lac society.
However, their numbers were small in comparison with that of farmers and craftsmen.
The Au Lac society, to a large extent, was similar to that of Van Lang, but the polarisation of the rich and the poor became more noticeable.
However, the unity and mutual assistance in villages and hamlets still remained profound and strong.
